metadata.document_name: 31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks
metadata.source_pdf: 31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
judges: C.HARI SHANKAR O R D E R (ORAL) % 18.01.2023 1.
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
appellants: Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited
key_issues: The appellant's application for registration of the device mark was rejected by the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act.
The rejection was based on the ground that the applied mark is similar to existing trade marks, specifically TM Nos 2045465 and 3131397, and that the services provided are also similar.
The appellant argued that the mark as a whole is different, but this argument was not found satisfactory by the Deputy Registrar.
The Deputy Registrar sustained the objection under Section 11(1) and refused the application, citing the likelihood of confusion between the applied mark and the cited conflicting marks.
The appellant's evidence of use of the mark subsequent to the date of application was not considered, as the mark was filed as "proposed to be used".

The Trade Marks Act's provision on relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 was applied in this case, highlighting the importance of considering similar trade marks and services when evaluating an application for registration.

The concept of "likelihood of confusion" is a key factor in determining whether a trade mark can be registered, and in this case, the Deputy Registrar found that there was a likelihood of confusion between the applied mark and existing marks.
The appellant's failure to provide a satisfactory explanation for the adoption of the mark was also a factor in the rejection of the application.
The registration of a trade mark on a "proposed to be used" basis is subject to certain conditions and requirements, and in this case, the appellant's application did not meet these requirements.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited vs. The Registrar of Trademarks**

**Background:**
The case involves an appeal by Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited (the appellant) against the decision of the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks (the respondent) to reject the appellant's application for registration of the device mark "Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel Foods" under the Trade Marks Act.

**Legal Issues:**
The main issue in this case is whether the appellant's device mark is registrable, given that there are existing trademarks (TM Nos. 2045465 and 3131397) that are similar to the appellant's mark and provide similar services. The respondent had rejected the appellant's application on the grounds of relative refusal under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, citing the likelihood of confusion between the applied mark and the existing marks.

**Arguments:**
The appellant's counsel, Mr. Manish Dhir, argued that the mark as a whole is different and that the appellant has been using the mark. The respondent, however, contended that the leading/dominant feature of the applied mark is "Oasis," which is similar to the existing marks, and that there is no explanation regarding the adoption of the mark. The respondent also noted that the evidence of use submitted by the appellant is subsequent to the date of application and cannot be considered.

**Court Findings:**
The High Court of Delhi (Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar) considered the submissions of both parties and perused the records. The court noted that the applied mark is not registrable due to the likelihood of confusion with the existing marks, as the leading feature of the applied mark is "Oasis," which is similar to the existing marks. The court also observed that the services provided by the appellant are similar to those provided by the proprietors of the existing marks.

**Decision:**
The court upheld the respondent's decision to reject the appellant's application for registration of the device mark. The court concluded that the applied mark is not registrable due to the likelihood of confusion with the existing marks and that the appellant's application was properly refused under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act.

**Key Points:**

* The appellant's device mark "Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel Foods" is not registrable due to the likelihood of confusion with existing marks (TM Nos. 2045465 and 3131397).
* The leading feature of the applied mark is "Oasis," which is similar to the existing marks.
* The services provided by the appellant are similar to those provided by the proprietors of the existing marks.
* The evidence of use submitted by the appellant is subsequent to the date of application and cannot be considered.
* The court upheld the respondent's decision to reject the appellant's application under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act.

--- PAGE 1 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 1 of 9 
 
$~78 (Original) 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
LITE BITE TRAVEL FOODS PRIVATE LIMITED 
..... Appellant 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
Mr. Manish Dhir, Adv.  
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
THE REGISTRAR OF TRADEMARKS 
    ..... Respondent 
Through: 
Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. 
Sagar Mehlawat and Mr. Alexander Mathai 
Paikaday, Advs. 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C.HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
     O R D E R (ORAL) 
% 
 
 
 
18.01.2023 
 
1. 
The appellant is aggrieved by the order dated 7th January 2021, 
passed by the learned Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks (“the learned 
Deputy Registrar”) whereby the application of the appellant for 
registration of the device mark 
  has been rejected.  
 
2. 
The impugned order reads thus: 
“IN THE MATTER OF Application No 3928838 
for registration of a trade mark Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel 
Foods filed by LITE BITE TRAVEL FOODS PRIVATE 
LIMITED.. 
 
आदेश/O R D E R 
 
Above application has been filed for registration of the 
trademark Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel Foods on 28/08/2018 
which was examined on 29/09/2018 and examination report was 
communicated to the applicant at his address for service. A reply to 
the office objection(s) had been filed on behalf of the applicant but 
the same was not found satisfactory and the application was set 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 2 of 9 
 
down for hearing and eventually hearing took place before me on 
09/11/2020.  
 
Adv. Manish Dhir Attorney appeared before me and made 
his/her submissions. I have heard arguments and gone through the 
records. 
 
Office objection u/sec. 11 (1) raised against the applied 
mark. 
 
Ld. Counsel submits mark as a whole different. Applicant is 
using the mark.  
 
Heard the Ld. Counsel and perused the record. 
 
Leading/Dominant feature of the applied mark is OASIS 
found common and similar to TM Nos. 2045465 and 3131397. 
Services also similar. No explanation regarding adoption. Mark 
filed as proposed to be used. Evidence of use subsequent to date of 
application. Can't be considered. Given, marks are remembered by 
broad expression, to my mind there is likelihood of confusion 
between applied mark and the said cited conflicting marks. 
Objection sustained. Application refused. 
 
After perusal of all the documents on record and 
submission made by the applicant / authorised agent it is concluded 
that applied mark is not registrable because of the reason stated as 
above. Hence application no 3928838 cannot be accepted and 
refused accordingly.  
 
दद न ां क/Dated: 07 January 2021. 
(SACHIN SHARMA) 
वररष्ठ परीक्षक, व्य प र दिह्न/DEPUTY REGISTRAR 
OF TRADE MARKS 
(अदिदनयम के 3 (2) के तहत प्र दिकृत)/(/Authorized 
under 3(2) of the Act)” 
 
3. 
The applicant applied for registration of the  
 
device mark on 28th August 2018. The applicant sought registration of 
the said mark in respect of services provided in restaurants, self-
service restaurants, services for providing food and drink, bar services, 
snakc-bars and cafes.  Registration was sought on a  “proposed to be 
used” basis, as a Service Provider.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 3 of 9 
 
4. 
Consequent on examination, the Examiner in the office of the 
Regsitrar of Trade Marks, vide his First Examination Report (FER), 
dated 29th September 2018, opined that the application of the appellant 
was “open to objection on relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 
of the Trade Marks Act”, as “same/similar trade mark(s) is/are already 
on record of the register for the same or similar goods/services”.   
 
5. 
The report purported to enclose details of the earlier existing 
trademarks, on the basis of which the Examiner had opined that the 
application of the appellant merited rejection.  
 
6. 
The details of the earlier registered marks, constituting the basis 
of the objections raised by the Examiner, as enclosed with the FER, 
may be reproduced thus: 
 
GOVERNMENT OF INDIA 
TRADE MARKS REGISTRY 
 
LOCATION: 
SECTION: EXM 
REPORT: EXM007 
WORD MARK SEARCH REPORT 
APPLICATION NUMBER: 3928838 
Class: --- 
TRADEMARK: 'Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel Foods 
USER: STK 
PAGE:1 
 
DATE: 17/09/2018 
 
APPL 
NO

APPLICATION DATE 27/10/2010 
GOODS/SERVICE CATERING SERVICES, PROVIDING OF FOODS AND DRINKS AND 
RESTAURANT SERVICES 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
3131397

GOYAL

APPLICATION DATE 19/12/2015

GOODS/SERVICE SERVICES FOR PROVIDING FOOD AND DRINK; 
RESTAURANTS, 
BAR, 
LOUNGE, 
TEMPORARY 
ACCOMMODATION, BANQUET, HOSPITALITY, HOTEL AND 
RESORT SERVICES. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 4 of 9 
 
3600149 
43 
 
 
NIKESH 
KISHOR GALA 
3/468 A, Kalyan 
Bhuvan, 
Maheshwari 
Udhyaan, 
Matunga 
East, 
Mumbai - 
400019. 
Maharashtra. 
Objected 
APPLICATION DATE 27/07/2017 
11:34:06 
 
GOODS/SERVICE Hotel; Motel; Restaurants; Self-Service Restaurant; Quick Service 
Restaurant; Bar Services; Cafe; Cafeteria; Canteen; Snack Bar; Food Court; Lounge; Take 
Away; Dine In; Food cart; Food Truck; Services for Providing Food, Drink, Beverage and 
Temporary Accommodation; Food, Drink and Beverage Catering; Rental of Furniture, Linens, 
Utensils, Table, Cooking apparatus, Lighting apparatus and other apparatus. 
 
7. 
The appellant submitted a reply, dated 11th February 2020, to 
the FER of the Examiner, in which it was contended, inter alia, thus: 
 
(i) 
The appellant had been continuously using the 
 mark for its services and was well known in the 
industry.  A user affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh, an authorised 
representative of the appellant, was also filed with the said reply, 
to vouchsage this contention. The affidavit annexed documents 
showing use of the 
 trade mark, under which 
mark, the appellant was running an outlet at the Mumbai 
International 
Airport. 
Placards, 
signboards 
and 
other 
representations available at the airport, as well as the illuminated 
signage outside the appellant’s premises at the airport, were also 
annexed.  
 
(ii) 
As such, the general public was well aware of the 
appelalnt’s 
outlet 
and 
invaribly 
associated 
the 
mark with the serivces provided by the appellant. 
 
(iii) 
The 
 mark relatable to Application No. 3131397 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 5 of 9 
 
of M/s Goel Fashions Pvt. Ltd. was not registered, as it was 
under objections.  This, therefore, could not constitute an “earlier 
trade mark”  for the purposes of Section 11 (1)(d) of the Trade 
Marks Act.  
(iv) 
Insofar as the 
 mark of M/s Capsulation Services 
Pvt. Ltd. (“Capsulation Services”) was concerned, the appellant 
claimed to be a bona fide adopter and user of the 
 
trade mark, who, by virtue of the extensive usage of the said 
mark, had earned its own reputation and goodwill and made a 
place for itself in the hospitality market.  
 
(v) 
The services provided by the appellant, under the 
mark were different from the services provided 
by capsulation services under the 
 mark. 
 
(vi) 
There was, therefore, no likelihood of confusion, if any, 
between 
 mark of the appellant and the 
 
mark of Capsulation Services, resulting in any confusion in the 
mind of the public, with respect to the entity with which the mark 
was associated or the services provided thereunder. 
 
(vii) 
The marks, seen as a whole, were clearly distinguishable. 
The appellant’s mark was 
 whereas the mark of  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 6 of 9 
 
Capsulation Services,  was 
. Besides, the marks were 
visually completely distintinct and constituted disntinct artistic 
representations.  
 
(viii) 
The appellant had never been communicated any 
objection or any other communication by anyone who claimed to 
have been confused as result of the adoption, by the appellant, of 
the  
 mark, for the registration of which the 
application had been filed.  
 
 
8. 
I have heard Mr. Manish Dhir, learned Counsel for the appellant 
and Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, learned Counsel for the respondent at 
some length. 
 
9. 
Plainly, the impugned order does not consider the various 
grounds urged by the appellant in its reply dated 11th February 2020 to 
the FER dated 29th September 2018. There is, equally, no reflection of 
any consideration of the affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh or the 
material that was filed therewith.  
 
10. 
In fact, the learned Deputy Registrar has, it appears, proceeded 
on a complete misreading of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act.  
The impugned order reflects the view that mere similarity of the 
marks, of which registration is sought, is, by itself, sufficient as a 
ground to reject the application seeking registration. That, however, is 
not the position as it obtains in law. Even statutorily, Section 11(1)((b) 
is subject to two other provisions/caveats.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 7 of 9 
 
11. 
Section 11(1) starts with the words “save as provided in Section 
12”. Section 12, therefore, operates as an exception to Section 11(1).  
Section 12 deals with entitlement to registration where, despite 
similarity of the marks, the applicant pleads honest and concurrent 
user. In the present case, the appellant has specifically pleaded honest 
and concurrent user. There is no reflection of any application of mind 
by the learned Registrar of Trademarks to the said contention. 
 
12. 
Additionally, similarity of the mark, of which registration is 
sought, coupled with identity or similarity of the goods or services 
covered by the said mark can constitute a basis for rejection of an 
application seeking registration of the mark, under Section 11(1)(b) 
only where, because of such similarity between the marks and identity 
and similarity of goods or services covered by the marks, there exists 
a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public or of the public 
associating the mark, of which registration is sought, with the earlier 
trade mark. 
 
13. 
The existence, or otherwise, of likelihood of confusion is an 
issue of fact. Until and unless, on facts, it is established that, owing to 
identity/similarity of the mark of which registration is sought, and of 
the goods/services covered thereby, with an earlier mark, there is 
likelihood of confusion/association in the mind of the public, 
registration cannot be refused on that ground.  
 
14. 
In the event that Section 11(1)(b) is stated as a ground for 
rejection of an application seeking registration of a mark, therefore, 
the impugned order must additionally contain a finding that, owing to 
similarity of the mark of which registration is sought with an earlier 
trade mark and identity/similarity of the goods and services covered 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 8 of 9 
 
by 
the 
said 
mark, 
there 
is 
a 
positive 
likelihood 
of 
confusion/association, on the part of the public, as envisaged by the 
provision.  Such a finding can be returned only after examining the 
facts and the material on record.  It cannot merely be chanted as a 
mantra. 
 
15. 
The appellant has raised several contentions in its reply dated 
11th February 2020 to the FER dated 29th September 2018. 
Additionally, an affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh, along with material 
substantiating the contentions raised in the reply, was also filed, and 
the impugned order does not reflect any examination or consideration 
of the submissions contained in the reply dated 11th February 2020, 
the affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh or the documents filed with the 
affidavit, I deem it appropriate that the matter be remanded to the 
learned Registrar of Trademarks for re-consideration.  
 
Conclusion 
 
16. 
Resultantly, the impugned order dated 7th January 2021 is 
quashed and set aside. The Application no. 3928838 dated 28th August 
2018 filed by the appellant for registration of the 
mark 
is remanded for re-consideration, from the stage of submission, by the 
appellant, of its reply dated 11th February 2020 to the FER dated 29th 
September 2018 of the Examiner. 
 
17. 
The appellant would be entitled to an opportunity of personal 
hearing before a decision is taken. In order to expedite matters, the 
appellant is directed to present itself before the concerned officer on 
30th January 2023.  The officer concerned is directed to consider the 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 9 of 9 
 
application as expeditiously as possible and take a fresh decision 
thereon, uninfluenced by impugned order dated 7th January 2021, 
within a period of four weeks therefrom, and to communicate the said 
decision to the appellant immediately thereupon. 
 
18. 
Without casting any aspersion on the learned Deputy Registrar, 
who passed the impugned order dated 7th January 2021, and keeping 
in mind the principle that justice should not only be done but must be 
seen to be done, as enunciated by the Supreme Court in P.V. 
Narasimha Rao v. State (CBI/SPE)1, the learned Registrar is 
requested to assign the task of adjudication to an officer other than the 
officer who has passed the impugned order dated 7th January 2021.  
 
19. 
It is made clear that this direction is not intended to cast any 
aspersion on the learned Deputy Registrar who passed the impugned 
order and is only intended to assuage any apprehension, in the minds 
of the appellant, that the officer has already pre-determined the issue. 
 
20. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly, with no order as to 
costs. 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
JANUARY 18, 2023 
 
dsn/AR 
                                          
1 MANU/SC/2319/1996 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021. The appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, was represented by Mr. Manish Dhir, while the respondent, The Registrar of Trade Marks, was represented by Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday.

The case involved the rejection of the appellant's application for registration of the device mark "Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel Foods" by the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on January 7, 2021. The application was filed on August 28, 2018, for services provided in restaurants, self-service restaurants, and food and drink services. The Deputy Registrar rejected the application due to a likelihood of confusion with existing trademarks (TM Nos. 2045465 and 3131397) and the dominant feature of the applied mark being "OASIS".

The appellant argued that the mark as a whole was different, but the Deputy Registrar sustained the objection and refused the application. The High Court, presided over by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, heard the oral order on January 18, 2023. The document provides details of the legal proceedings, including dates, parties, and arguments presented. (Source: Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

nodes.title: Page 1
nodes.summary: According to page 1 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi is hearing an appeal by Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited against the Registrar of Trade Marks. The appellant is challenging the order dated January 7, 2021, which rejected their application for registration of the device mark "Oasis Lounge By Lite Bite Travel Foods" (Application No 3928838). The application was filed on August 28, 2018, and examined on September 29, 2018. The applicant's reply to the office objections was found unsatisfactory, leading to the rejection. The appeal is being heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, with Mr. Manish Dhir representing the appellant and Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday representing the respondent. The court proceedings are recorded with a Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000482 and C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021.

nodes.summary: According to page 2 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court heard the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 on November 9, 2020. Advocate Manish Dhir represented the appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited. The registrar of trademarks raised an objection under Section 11(1) due to the similarity of the applied mark with existing trademarks (TM Nos. 2045465 and 3131397). The leading feature of the applied mark, "OASIS", was found to be common and similar to the cited marks, and the services provided were also similar. The court sustained the objection and refused the application for registration, noting that the applied mark is not registrable due to the likelihood of confusion with the existing marks. The decision was made on January 7, 2021, by Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, Sachin Sharma.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021. The appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, was represented by Mr. Manish Dhir, while the respondent, The Registrar of Trade Marks, was represented by Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday.

The case revolved around the registration of a trademark. The Examiner in the office of the Registrar of Trade Marks had raised objections to the appellant's application under Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, citing existing similar trademarks. The Examiner's First Examination Report, dated September 29, 2018, listed three earlier registered marks, including "OASIS" (Application No. 2045465) and "OASIS" (Application No. 3131397), which were considered similar to the appellant's mark.

The appellant responded to the Examiner's report on February 11, 2020, arguing that they had been continuously using their mark and were well-known in the industry. They submitted a user affidavit and documents showing use of the trademark at the Mumbai International Airport.

The case highlights the importance of trademark registration and the potential for conflicts with existing marks. As reported in the PDF document, the court considered the objections raised by the Examiner and the appellant's response in determining the outcome of the case. (Source: "Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000482)

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary: According to page 3 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the Examiner of the Trade Marks Registry issued a First Examination Report (FER) on September 29, 2018, stating that the application of Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited was "open to objection on relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act". The Examiner found that similar trademarks were already registered for the same or similar goods/services. The report cited two existing trademarks: "OASIS" registered by Capsulation Services Pvt. Ltd. (Application No. 2045465) and "OASIS" applied by Goyal Fashions Pvt. Ltd. (Application No. 3131397). The PDF source provides details of the legal proceedings, including the application dates and goods/services related to the trademarks. (Source: 31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 3 of 9 
 
4. 
Consequent on examination, the Examiner in the office of the 
Regsitrar of Trade Marks, vide his First Examination Report (FER), 
dated 29th September 2018, opined that the application of the appellant 
was “open to objection on relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 
of the Trade Marks Act”, as “same/similar trade mark(s) is/are already 
on record of the register for the same or similar goods/services”.   
 
5. 
The report purported to enclose details of the earlier existing 
trademarks, on the basis of which the Examiner had opined that the 
application of the appellant merited rejection.  
 
6. 
The details of the earlier registered marks, constituting the basis 
of the objections raised by the Examiner, as enclosed with the FER, 
may be reproduced thus:

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, submitted a reply to the Examiner's First Examination Report (FER) on February 11, 2020. The reply contended that the appellant had been continuously using the trade mark for its services and was well-known in the industry. A user affidavit from Sukhpreet Singh, an authorized representative, was filed to support this claim, along with documents showing use of the trade mark at the Mumbai International Airport. The appellant argued that the general public was aware of its outlet and associated the mark with its services. The application date for the trade mark was July 27, 2017. (Source: PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 4)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021. The appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, was represented by Mr. Manish Dhir, while the respondent, The Registrar of Trade Marks, was represented by Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday.

The appellant argued that their trade mark was not similar to existing marks, including those of M/s Goel Fashions Pvt. Ltd. and M/s Capsulation Services Pvt. Ltd. They claimed to be a bona fide adopter and user of the trade mark, with extensive usage and reputation in the hospitality market. The appellant also stated that their services were different from those of Capsulation Services, and there was no likelihood of confusion between the two marks.

The court noted that the impugned order did not consider the various grounds urged by the appellant and that the learned Deputy Registrar had misread Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act. The court also mentioned that Section 12, which deals with entitlement to registration where there is honest and concurrent user, was not applied in this case. The appellant had pleaded honest and concurrent user, but there was no reflection of this in the decision. (Source: Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf, Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000482)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, argued that they are a bona fide adopter and user of their trade mark, having earned their own reputation and goodwill in the hospitality market. They claimed that their services are different from those provided by Capsulation Services Pvt. Ltd. and that there is no likelihood of confusion between their marks. The appellant's mark is distinguishable from Capsulation Services' mark. The case, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021, is being heard in the High Court of Delhi, with Mr. Manish Dhir representing the appellant and Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday representing the respondent, the Registrar of Trade Marks. (Source: PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 5)

under objections.  This, therefore, could not constitute an “earlier 
trade mark”  for the purposes of Section 11 (1)(d) of the Trade 
Marks Act.

between

(vii) 
The marks, seen as a whole, were clearly distinguishable.

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
According to page 6 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, argued that their mark is visually distinct and constitutes a distinct artistic representation. The appellant also stated that they had never received any communication from anyone claiming to be confused by their mark. 

The court heard arguments from Mr. Manish Dhir, Counsel for the appellant, and Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Counsel for the respondent. The impugned order was found to not consider the appellant's grounds and the affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh. The Deputy Registrar misread Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, believing that mere similarity of marks is sufficient to reject an application. 

The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021, with a Neutral Citation Number of 2023/DHC/000482, and was digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi on January 23, 2023.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 6 of 9 
 
Capsulation Services,  was 
. Besides, the marks were 
visually completely distintinct and constituted disntinct artistic 
representations.  
 
(viii) 
The appellant had never been communicated any 
objection or any other communication by anyone who claimed to 
have been confused as result of the adoption, by the appellant, of 
the  
 mark, for the registration of which the 
application had been filed.  
 
 
8. 
I have heard Mr. Manish Dhir, learned Counsel for the appellant 
and Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, learned Counsel for the respondent at 
some length. 
 
9. 
Plainly, the impugned order does not consider the various 
grounds urged by the appellant in its reply dated 11th February 2020 to 
the FER dated 29th September 2018. There is, equally, no reflection of 
any consideration of the affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh or the 
material that was filed therewith.  
 
10. 
In fact, the learned Deputy Registrar has, it appears, proceeded 
on a complete misreading of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act.  
The impugned order reflects the view that mere similarity of the 
marks, of which registration is sought, is, by itself, sufficient as a 
ground to reject the application seeking registration. That, however, is 
not the position as it obtains in law. Even statutorily, Section 11(1)((b) 
is subject to two other provisions/caveats.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses Section 11(1) and Section 12 of the Trade Marks Act. The appellant, Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited, has pleaded honest and concurrent user, but the Registrar of Trade Marks has not considered this contention. The court notes that similarity of marks and goods/services can only be a basis for rejection under Section 11(1)(b) if there is a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public. The existence of likelihood of confusion is an issue of fact that must be established. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/000482. The court is considering the appeal against the Registrar's decision, with the appellant represented by Mr. Manish Dhir and the respondent represented by Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 7 of 9 
 
11. 
Section 11(1) starts with the words “save as provided in Section 
12”. Section 12, therefore, operates as an exception to Section 11(1).  
Section 12 deals with entitlement to registration where, despite 
similarity of the marks, the applicant pleads honest and concurrent 
user. In the present case, the appellant has specifically pleaded honest 
and concurrent user. There is no reflection of any application of mind 
by the learned Registrar of Trademarks to the said contention. 
 
12. 
Additionally, similarity of the mark, of which registration is 
sought, coupled with identity or similarity of the goods or services 
covered by the said mark can constitute a basis for rejection of an 
application seeking registration of the mark, under Section 11(1)(b) 
only where, because of such similarity between the marks and identity 
and similarity of goods or services covered by the marks, there exists 
a likelihood of confusion on the part of the public or of the public 
associating the mark, of which registration is sought, with the earlier 
trade mark. 
 
13. 
The existence, or otherwise, of likelihood of confusion is an 
issue of fact. Until and unless, on facts, it is established that, owing to 
identity/similarity of the mark of which registration is sought, and of 
the goods/services covered thereby, with an earlier mark, there is 
likelihood of confusion/association in the mind of the public, 
registration cannot be refused on that ground.  
 
14. 
In the event that Section 11(1)(b) is stated as a ground for 
rejection of an application seeking registration of a mark, therefore, 
the impugned order must additionally contain a finding that, owing to 
similarity of the mark of which registration is sought with an earlier 
trade mark and identity/similarity of the goods and services covered 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:23.01.2023
17:07:48
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
The court decision in the case of Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks (PDF source: 2023/DHC/000482, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021) revolves around the appeal filed by Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited against the decision of the Registrar of Trade Marks. The appellant had applied for registration of a trademark, which was opposed by the Registrar. 

The court, Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, allowed the appeal, quashing and setting aside the impugned order dated January 7, 2021. The application for registration of the trademark was remanded for re-consideration from the stage of submission of the appellant's reply dated February 11, 2020, to the First Examination Report (FER) dated September 29, 2018.

The court directed the appellant to present itself before the concerned officer on January 30, 2023, and the officer was instructed to consider the application expeditiously and take a fresh decision within four weeks, uninfluenced by the impugned order. The Registrar was also requested to assign the task of adjudication to an officer other than the one who passed the impugned order to ensure fairness and transparency.

The appeal was allowed with no order as to costs. The decision was made on January 18, 2023, and digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi on January 23, 2023. The PDF source provides detailed information about the court proceedings, including the dates, parties, and arguments presented.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court found that the Registrar of Trademarks did not consider the appellant's reply dated 11th February 2020 and the affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh. The court quashed and set aside the impugned order dated 7th January 2021 and remanded the application for re-consideration from the stage of submission of the appellant's reply. The appellant is entitled to a personal hearing, which was scheduled for 30th January 2023. The court directed the concerned officer to consider the submissions and make a decision. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/000482. The judges and advocates involved include HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C.HARI SHA, Mr. Manish Dhir, Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. Sagar Mehlawat, and Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday. (Source: PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 8)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 8 of 9 
 
by 
the 
said 
mark, 
there 
is 
a 
positive 
likelihood 
of 
confusion/association, on the part of the public, as envisaged by the 
provision.  Such a finding can be returned only after examining the 
facts and the material on record.  It cannot merely be chanted as a 
mantra. 
 
15. 
The appellant has raised several contentions in its reply dated 
11th February 2020 to the FER dated 29th September 2018. 
Additionally, an affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh, along with material 
substantiating the contentions raised in the reply, was also filed, and 
the impugned order does not reflect any examination or consideration 
of the submissions contained in the reply dated 11th February 2020, 
the affidavit of Mr. Sukhpreet Singh or the documents filed with the 
affidavit, I deem it appropriate that the matter be remanded to the 
learned Registrar of Trademarks for re-consideration.  
 
Conclusion 
 
16. 
Resultantly, the impugned order dated 7th January 2021 is 
quashed and set aside. The Application no. 3928838 dated 28th August 
2018 filed by the appellant for registration of the 
mark 
is remanded for re-consideration, from the stage of submission, by the 
appellant, of its reply dated 11th February 2020 to the FER dated 29th 
September 2018 of the Examiner. 
 
17. 
The appellant would be entitled to an opportunity of personal 
hearing before a decision is taken. In order to expedite matters, the 
appellant is directed to present itself before the concerned officer on 
30th January 2023.  The officer concerned is directed to consider the

By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary: According to page 9 of the PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court has directed the Registrar of Trade Marks to reconsider the application and make a fresh decision within four weeks. The court has also requested that the task of adjudication be assigned to an officer other than the one who passed the impugned order dated January 7, 2021, to avoid any apprehension of pre-determination. The appeal has been allowed with no order as to costs. The decision was made by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar on January 18, 2023. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021, with Lite Bite Travel Foods Private Limited as the appellant and the Registrar of Trade Marks as the respondent. (Source: PDF "31. Lite Bite Travel Foods Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 9)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000482 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 4/2021 
 
Page 9 of 9 
 
application as expeditiously as possible and take a fresh decision 
thereon, uninfluenced by impugned order dated 7th January 2021, 
within a period of four weeks therefrom, and to communicate the said 
decision to the appellant immediately thereupon. 
 
18. 
Without casting any aspersion on the learned Deputy Registrar, 
who passed the impugned order dated 7th January 2021, and keeping 
in mind the principle that justice should not only be done but must be 
seen to be done, as enunciated by the Supreme Court in P.V. 
Narasimha Rao v. State (CBI/SPE)1, the learned Registrar is 
requested to assign the task of adjudication to an officer other than the 
officer who has passed the impugned order dated 7th January 2021.  
 
19. 
It is made clear that this direction is not intended to cast any 
aspersion on the learned Deputy Registrar who passed the impugned 
order and is only intended to assuage any apprehension, in the minds 
of the appellant, that the officer has already pre-determined the issue. 
 
20. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly, with no order as to 
costs. 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
JANUARY 18, 2023 
 
dsn/AR 
                                          
1 MANU/SC/2319/1996 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
